coredata.dc:description: Quasi-solid electrolytes (QSEs) with high safety and flexibility can provide relatively high ionic conductivity and electrode/electrolyte interface compatibility. However, it also suffers from challenges of mechanical strength and stable cycling at room temperature. Herein, we design and prepare a poly(ionic liquid) electrolyte by in-situ thermally initiate crosslinking polymerization of poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate (PEGMEM) and 1-vinyl-3-isobutyrate ethyl imidazole bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl) imide (VBIM-TFSI) on the electrode surface with polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS)/polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) electrospun membrane as reinforcement separator. The POSS/PVDF electrospun membrane improves the electrolyte's mechanical strength without compromising the thickness, while the stable lithium-ion transport channels in the cross-linked network by PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI enhance the ionic conductivity, achieving stable cycling of the battery at ambient temperature. The electrolyte with molar ratio of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI of 1–2 (QSE-P1I2) exhibits high ionic conductivity (2.15 × 10−4 S cm−1, 30 °C) and stable electrode/electrolyte interface properties. Meanwhile, the batteries assembled with QSE-P1I2 realize stable cycle at room temperature. This study provides a promising strategy to utilize in-situ polymerization to improve electrode/electrolyte interfacial compatibility, improve ionic conductivity, and realize room temperature cycling of solid-state batteries.

head.ce:title: In-situ generation of poly(ionic liquid) flexible quasi-solid electrolyte supported by polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane / polyvinylidene fluoride electrospun membrane for lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi'an, 710129, People's Republic of China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi'an, 710129, People's Republic of China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Quasi-solid electrolytes (QSEs) with high safety and flexibility can provide relatively high ionic conductivity and electrode/electrolyte interface compatibility. However, it also suffers from challenges of mechanical strength and stable cycling at room temperature. Herein, we design and prepare a poly(ionic liquid) electrolyte by in-situ thermally initiate crosslinking polymerization of poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate (PEGMEM) and 1-vinyl-3-isobutyrate ethyl imidazole bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl) imide (VBIM-TFSI) on the electrode surface with polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS)/polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) electrospun membrane as reinforcement separator. The POSS/PVDF electrospun membrane improves the electrolyte's mechanical strength without compromising the thickness, while the stable lithium-ion transport channels in the cross-linked network by PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI enhance the ionic conductivity, achieving stable cycling of the battery at ambient temperature. The electrolyte with molar ratio of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI of 1–2 (QSE-P1I2) exhibits high ionic conductivity (2.15 × 10−4 S cm−1, 30 °C) and stable electrode/electrolyte interface properties. Meanwhile, the batteries assembled with QSE-P1I2 realize stable cycle at room temperature. This study provides a promising strategy to utilize in-situ polymerization to improve electrode/electrolyte interfacial compatibility, improve ionic conductivity, and realize room temperature cycling of solid-state batteries.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: The data that has been used is confidential.

ce:section.ce:para: The vigorous promotion of new energy vehicles has promoted the development of new energy storage technology [1–3]. Li-ion batteries with the advantages of high energy density and no memory effect have been received the widest attention [4]. Lithium metal is an ideal anode material due to the high theoretical specific capacity and low redox potential [5,6]. Nevertheless, due to the lithium metal's high reactivity and the uneven production of dendritic lithium dendrites during electroplating/stripping, the battery capacity fade rapidly and even fails [7,8]. Lithium metal anode enable applications by matching with low reactive solid electrolyte, which dissolving lithium salt in the polymer matrix [9]. Additionally, the high mechanical strength of solid electrolyte could inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites, avoiding safety problems caused by internal short circuits [10].

Polyethylene oxide (PEO), a flexible semi-crystalline polymer, serves as a common electrolyte matrix material that can dissolve lithium salts and transfer Li+ through coordination/dissociation with Li+ in the amorphous region [9]. Nevertheless, PEO with high molecular weight has regular linear structure and is easy to crystallize at room temperature, which is not conducive to the transport of Li+ [11]. The introduction of oligoethylene oxide is an effective strategy to reduce the crystallization of solid electrolytes. Ma and co-workers synthesized star-shaped polymer of POSS−(PMMA−PPEGMEM)8 with octachloropropyl polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane as a template and poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate as a conductive unit by free radical polymerization [12]. The crystallinity of solid electrolyte prepared with POSS−(PMMA−PPEGMEM)8 as the polymer matrix was markedly reduced, and the ionic conductivity was significantly improved (4.9 × 10−5 cm−1, 30 °C). Incorporation of a cross-linked network is another feasible approach to reduce the crystallinity of solid electrolytes, while improving the electrode/electrolyte interface compatibility due to cross-linking polymerization occurring on the electrode surface. Wei et al. developed a cross-linked electrolyte on the electrode surface with a common ionic conductivity (2.95 × 10−5 S cm−1, 30 °C) and outstanding lithium metal electrode compatibility over 800 h [13]. Yang et al. used polyacrylate as the main chain and the oligomeric ethylene oxide chain terminated with –OCH3 unit as the side chain to form an electrolyte with three-dimensional structure by in-situ polymerization, and the network structure could effectively minimize the electrolyte's crystallinity while providing high ionic conductivity (4.6 × 10−4 S cm−1) [14]. However, the high rigidity of the cross-linked network led to low mechanical strength of the electrolyte (0.02 MPa). The porous membranes used as carrier alleviate the challenge of high rigidity of the cross-linked electrolyte and improve mechanical properties. Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) is a widely used material in polymer electrolyte due to the excellent stability and mechanical strength [15]. It can impart high mechanical strength to the electrolyte to resist the penetration of lithium dendrites and generate LiF with the lithium anode to improve the interfacial stability of the electrolyte/electrode [16]. The intramolecular organic-inorganic hybrid polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) has a cage-shaped inorganic core formed by Si–O–Si and organic structural units bonded to the silicon vertices, which the inorganic nano structure gives the material high thermal and mechanical stability and the organic structure can improve its compatibility with polymers [17–19]. POSS is usually used to modify polymers to improve the mechanical strength and thermal stability of materials. POSS-reinforced PVDF electrospun membranes with excellent mechanical properties and high thermal stability are ideal candidates for electrolyte reinforcements [20]. The high crystallinity of PVDF provide high mechanical strength for electrolyte [21]. In addition, the rigid POSS composed of Si–O further enhance the mechanical strength of the spun films, while improving the thermal stability.

The development of new polymer systems is a new direction to obtain high-performance electrolytes. Poly(ionic liquid) (PIL) is a new type of functional polymers covalently attached to the polymer chain and retains the characteristics of high ionic conductivity, thermal stability and electrochemical stability of ionic liquids [22]. Bao and co-workers fabricated an electrolyte blended with poly(ionic liquid) and PEO and found imidazole-based poly(ionic liquid) had strong ionic dipole interactions with ethoxy groups which can weaken the crystallization of PEO [23]. In addition, Peng et al. discovered that the interaction between the TFSI− anion and the quaternary ammonium salt cation boosted lithium salt dissociation, which improved ionic conductivity even more [24]. Therefore, poly(ionic liquid) is considered as promising materials for improving the electrical properties of solid-state electrolytes.

In this study, we design and fabricate an in-situ generation of poly(ionic liquid) of 1-vinyl-3-isobutyrate ethyl imidazole bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl) imide (VBIM-TFSI) and poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate (PEGMEM) as monomers flexible quasi-solid electrolyte supported by electrospun membrane of POSS/PVDF to improve the electrode/electrolyte interfacial compatibility. The ionic liquid on the cross-linked network can immobilize and inhibit the shuttling of anions, while PEGMEM can be constructed to form Li+ transport channels, which bestows the electrolyte with high ionic conductivity, ion transference number and excellent room temperature cycling performance. Meanwhile, the POSS-enhanced PVDF matrix film endows the electrolyte with increased mechanical strength and thermal stability. In addition, the in-situ thermally initiate crosslinking on the electrode surface could form a stable interface between the electrode/electrolyte to improve the charge-discharge cycle stability and increase the working life. This study shows a new approach to make lithium metal battery electrolytes with strong ionic conductivity and good heat resistance.

1-Vinylimidazole, ethyl α-bromoisobutyrate, poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate (PEGMEM, Mw ≈ 475), poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA, Mw ≈ 600), azodiisobutyronitrile (AIBN) and lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulphonyl) imide (LiTFSI) are purchased from Aladdin. Ethyl acetate and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) is provided by Guangdong Guanghua Technology Co., Ltd. Ethylene carbonate and propylene carbonate is supplied from Macklin. Lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4) and acetylene black are provided by Xi'an Sifu Energy Technology Co., Ltd. Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF, Kynar 761) is provided by Arkema. Octa(3-chloropropyl)-polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS-(C3H6Cl)8) is synthesized by dehydration condensation according to our previous work [20,25].

The VBIM-TFSI was synthesized according to the following method. The 1-vinylimidazole (0.05 mol) and ethyl 2-bromoisobutyrate (0.06 mol) were blended and stirred in a round bottom flask to obtain a uniform solution. The mixed solution was reacted for 24 h at 75 °C. The crude product (VBIM-Br) was washed several times with ethyl acetate to remove unreacted reactants, after being naturally cooled to ambient temperature. Ionic liquids containing TFSI-anions were prepared by a simple ion exchange method. In 10 ml deionized water, the VBIM-Br (0.015 mol) and LiTFSI (0.018 mol) were dissolved and stirred for 4 h. Then, A considerable amount of deionized water was used to wash the resultant brown oily liquid (VBIM-TFSI) to remove the extra lithium salt. The VBIM-TFSI was dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 24 h. The detailed synthesis route was shown in Fig. S1.

1H nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) and fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy were used to confirm the chemical structure of VBIM-TFSI (Fig. S2). 1H NMR (δ in ppm): 1.3–1.4 (O–CH2–CH 3, 3H, t); 1.9 (CH3, 6H); 4.3–4.4 (O–CH 2–CH3, 2H, q); 5.4–5.6 (CH CH 2, 1H, dd); 5.7–5.9 (CH CH 2,1H, dd); 7.3–7.4 (CH CH2, 1H, dd); 7.62–7.84 (–NCHCHN–, d, 2H); 9.1(–NCHN–, s, 1H) [26,27]. FT-IR, ν max/cm−1: γ-CH3 2995, γ-CHCH2 3150, 1657, γ-RCOOŔ 1741, 1354, imidazole ring 1551, TFSI− 572, 615, 737, 800, 1058 and 1191 [26,28].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation and characterization of POSS/PVDF electrospun membrane
ce:section.ce:para: The POSS/PVDF membrane was prepared by electrospinning, in which the spinning solution (14%, 16%, 18% and 20%) used an appropriate amount of DMF as the solvent to dissolve the PVDF and 10% POSS-(C3H6Cl)8. Using an electrospinning machine, 2 mL spinning solution was loaded into a syringe and sprayed onto a receiver at an extrusion rate of 0.05 mL/min under a dropout voltage of 13 kV. The electrospun membranes were dried at 60 °C under vacuum for 24 h, which were marked as P-x% (x = 14%, 16%, 18% and 20%).

The surface micromorphology of electrospun PVDF membranes was characterized by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Verios G4). The porosity (P) of the porous electrospun membrane was evaluated by the n-butanol absorption technique, where the electrospun membranes were submerged for 1 h in the n-butanol. The P was calculated according to

The solution uptake (η) of the electrospun membranes indicates its ability to absorb precursor solution. The spinning membrane was sandwiched between two glass plates and soaked in PC/EC (v/v = 1/1) solution for 1 h. The excess solvent on the membrane surface was absorbed with filter paper. By obtaining the mass of the membrane before and after absorbing the liquid, the η of the electrospun membrane can be obtained, which was calculated by

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of poly(ionic liquid) quasi-solid electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: The poly(ionic liquid) quasi-solid electrolyte with POSS/PVDF electrospun membrane as support was prepared by polymerizing the precursor solution on the electrode surface. (Fig. 1 ). Firstly, the precursor solutions containing VBIM-TFSI, PEGDA and PEGMEM were prepared, where the molar ratio of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI was from 3:1 to 1:3 (PEGMEM (P): VBIM-TFSI (I) = 3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2 and 1:3, 0.6 mmol in total), and the crosslinker of PEGDA was set at 3 mol% of the precursor solution. In addition, PC/EC, which was 15 times the mass of LiTFSI (60 mg), was used as a plasticizer to dissolve and disperse lithium salts and reactive monomers. To create a homogenous solution, the mixture was agitated for 6 h at room temperature. Then, the initiator of AIBN with a content of 0.5 wt% in the reactive monomer was added to the combined solution and agitated for 2 h. The precursor solution with 40 μL was injected into the POSS/PVDF electrospun membrane on the surface of the electrode with a pipette to prepare the electrolyte by stewing 12 h at 80 °C. The electrolytes were labeled as QSE-PxIy (x:y = 3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, 1:3) according to the molar ratio of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI. All procedures were carried out in an argon-filled glove box, which had oxygen and moisture below 0.1 ppm, respectively.

Bruker TENSOR 37 was used to capture the FT-IR spectra of the QSE-PxIy in the spectral area 700–4000 cm−1. 1H NMR was used to determine the structure of ionic liquid with CDCl3 as a deuterated reagent. The morphologies and the dispersion of the element of PVDF electrospun membrane, QSE-PxIy and lithium anode after cycling were observed by high-resolution field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, Verios G4) and the mapping mode of energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA, Mettler-Toledo) was used to assess the thermal stability of QSE-PxIy from 25 to 1000 °C with a scan rate of 10 °C min−1 under a nitrogen environment. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried to characterize the crystallization of electrolyte by Bruker D2 PHASER X with a scan rate of 0.04° min−1 between 10 and 50. Xray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Kratos AXIS Ultra DLD) was used to analyze material element valences.

The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), linear sweep voltammograms (LSV), cyclic voltammetry (CV) and the chronoamperometry were used to determine the ionic conductivities, electrochemical stabilization window and Li+ transference numbers of QSE-PxIy, where the sample batteries were assembled in 2016 coin-type in the Ar-filled glovebox. The ionic conductivity of the QSE-PxIy was obtained by EIS using the stainless-steel (SS) blocking symmetric battery on an AutoLab workstation from 30 to 80 °C with an amplitude of 10 mV in a frequency range of 1 Hz–100 kHz and determined by formula
σ = L /
( R ⋅ S )
, where the L, R and S represent the thickness, bulk resistance of the QSE-PxIy and the effective contacting area of blocking electrodes, respectively. The electrochemical stability windows (ESWs) of the QSE-PxIy were investigated using a SS||QSE-PxIy||Li cell by linear sweep voltammetry from 2.0 to 5.0 V (vs Li/Li+) with a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. The CV of SS||QSE-P1I2||Li was used to characterize the plating/stripping reversibility of Li with a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 between −0.6–3 V. The lithium-ion transfer number (tLi +) of the QSE-PxIy was determined by the chronoamperometry and EIS measurements before and after application of a DC polarization and calculated by the Bruce−Vincent−Evans equation

, where ΔV is the polarization voltage of 10 mV, the I0 and Iss represent the initial current and the steady-state current, R0 and Rss are the bulk resistances before and after applying the DC voltage, respectively. The CV of LiFePO4||QSE-P1I2||Li was carried with a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 at a voltage range of 2.7–4.0 V. To investigate the stability against lithium metal, a Li stripping/plating cycling test was done on the LAND CT2001A battery testing system with the Li||QSE-PxIy||Li cell at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 and a charge/discharge period of 30/30 min. On the multichannel LAND-CT2001A test system, the cycling tests of LiFePO4||Li battery and LiCoO2||Li battery with the LiFePO4 (or LiCoO2)/PVDF/superP (80/10/10, wt%) as cathode and Li metal as anode were operated at ambient temperature and 60 °C. The LiFePO4||Li pouch batteries were assembled for safety research and charge-discharge test.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Properties of POSS modified PVDF electrospun membrane
ce:section.ce:para: In order to enhance the electrolyte's mechanical properties, the polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) modified polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) electrospun membrane was used as the supporting membrane. The POSS/PVDF membranes were prepared by electrospinning, which were labeled as PVDF-x% according to the mass fraction of PVDF in solution. The morphology and diameter distribution of the POSS/PVDF electrospun membranes are shown in Fig. 2 (a)-(d). The silicon element in POSS-(C3H6Cl)8 could enhance the conductivity of the solution to increase the charge density of the jet, which in turn promotes the splitting of the jet into nanofibers [31]. In addition, the fiber diameter gradually increased with increasing polymer solution concentration due to the jet of high viscosity solution is delayed in the process of spraying to the receiver [32]. For example, PVDF-14% fibers have an average diameter of about 202.4 nm, while PVDF-18% fibers are about 365.2 nm. The increase of fiber diameter is conducive to the increase of fiber membrane pore diameter [33]. Besides, the uniform fiber diameter is beneficial to the mechanical properties of the spun membrane [34].

The interconnected porous structure stacked by electrospinning helps to form a connected ion transport channel through the reaction of the absorbed precursor solution. High porosity is required for the fiber membrane to accommodate enough precursor solution to achieve high ionic conductivity. The PVDF membrane with 18% concentration has the highest porosity due to the 18% PVDF spun fibers were uniform, as shown in Fig. 2(e). High porosity can provide more space to accommodate more liquid, which corresponds to PVDF membranes' electrolyte uptake (Fig. 2(f)). The high electrolyte uptake is conducive to the matrix film to absorb more precursor liquid, which provides more ion transport channels for Li+ after polymerization on the electrode surface [35].

The poly(ionic liquid) electrolyte of QSE-PxIy supported by POSS/PVDF can improve the mechanical property and thermal stability. The QSE-PxIy could simplify the polymerization process and improve the interfacial compatibility of electrode/electrolyte (Fig. 1). The precursor mixed solution dripped into the porous electrospun membrane is crosslinked and polymerized at 80 °C to form a double-network solid electrolyte, as shown in Fig. S3. The morphology and structure of QSE-PxIy are carefully studied by SEM.

From the microscopic topography of the surface and cross-section of QSE-PI (Fig. 3 ), the POSS/PVDF electrospun membrane is densely packed with cross-linked polymers, which is favorable for the formation of continuous ion channels. The uniform fold distribution on QSE-PxIy can be observed in the surface and enlarged cross-section, which is due to the microphase separation of the polymerized PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI from PVDF during polymerizing process [36]. Besides, the thickness of 54.5 μm could shorten Li+ transference distance, which is conducive to the improvement of battery rate performance. As shown in the energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS) mapping, the distribution of fluorine, silicon and nitrogen elements is uniform. Since only POSS contains silicon element and VBIM-TFSI contains nitrogen element, the uniform distribution of silicon and nitrogen indicates that POSS is uniformly dispersed in the backbone of PVDF electrospun membrane and VBIM-TFSI is uniformly distributed in QSE-PxIy, respectively [35].

The FT-IR of the cross-linking agent (PEGDA), the polymerized monomers (VBIM-TFSI and PEGMEM) and QSE-PxIy are shown in Fig. 4 (a). The stretching vibration absorption peak of imidazole ring in VBIM-TFSI is situated in 1542 cm−1, while the characteristic absorption peaks at 1351, 1279, 1187 and 1097 cm−1 belong to TFSI−1 [37]. The absorption peak of CO at 1718 cm−1 shows that ethyl 2-bromoisobutyrate is successfully connected to the imidazole ring. In addition, the CC stretching vibration peaks of PEGMEM, PEGDA and VBIM-TFSI are clearly visible at 1629 cm−1, but disappeared in the spectrum of QSE-PxIy, indicating that the cross-linking polymerization is successful and complete.

Excellent mechanical strength can suppress the lithium dendrites from developing and growing during battery charging and discharging, while good flexibility is also crucial for the fabrication of flexible batteries [38]. The electrolyte cross-linked by the precursor solution without supported by the POSS/PVDF electrospun membrane is brittle and fragile, and cannot be used as an electrolyte membrane alone in Li-ion batteries. However, the QSE-PxIy reinforced with POSS/PVDF membrane has higher flexibility and strength, which can both have high compatibility with electrodes and resist the effect of lithium dendrites. The mechanical properties of the QSE-PxIy are evaluated by stress-strain curves and the findings are displayed in Fig. 4(b) and Table S1. QSE-P3I1 had the highest tensile stress (1.55 MPa), while QSE-P1I3 had the highest elongation at break (215.6%). The mechanical properties of the QSE-PxIy electrolyte showed a trend of first decreasing and then increasing with the increase of VBIM-TFSI content in the system, which was due to the fact that the cross-linked network structure of the electrolyte was composed of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI with large volume differences. The cross-linked network structure dominated by PEGMEM (QSE-P3I1) or VBIM-TFSI (QSE-P1I3) has a weaker degree of deformity of the cross-linked network structure caused by the volume difference of the monomers and has a large fault tolerance space, which shows high strength in mechanical properties. However, when the crosslinking system with a small content difference between PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI, the crosslinking network structure is seriously distorted, which is not conducive to resisting the influence of external forces, resulting in the reduction of mechanical strength.

The electrolyte's good thermal stability assures the battery's safety in the case of thermal abuse, which is an important indicator in the practical application [39]. The TGA curves of the cross-linked QSE-PxIy formed with different molar ratios of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI are shown in Fig. 4(c). The thermal stability of the electrolyte displays an increasing trend as the ionic liquid content in the electrolyte increases. From 105 °C to 280 °C, the initial weight loss of QSE-PxIy is related to the decomposition of PEGDA and PEGMEM, and the secondary weight loss that occurred in the range of 280 °C–378 °C is caused by the decomposition of the PVDF support membrane, while the disintegration of the PIL chain causes tertiary weight loss above 378 °C [40]. Increasing the temperature to 400 °C results in the residual weight of QSE-PxIy greater than 10%, which is related to the POSS with high thermal stability in PVDF membrane.

XRD analysis was performed on the POSS/PVDF electrospun membrane and electrolytes formed by cross-linking polymerization of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI with different molar ratios to explore the effect of the cross-linking structure on the crystalline properties of the electrolyte, as shown in Fig. 4(d). The characteristic absorption peak of PVDF in POSS/PVDF can be observed at 20.4° [41]. However, except for the special crystalline peaks of POSS/PVDF, no new crystalline diffraction peaks were observed in all electrolytes in the XRD patterns, indicating that the cross-linked network makes PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI, which are used to form ion transport channels in the electrolytes, exist in an amorphous state.

The dimensional stability of the electrolyte at high temperature directly reflect its heat resistance [42]. The dimensional changes of different electrolyte membranes after standing in an oven at the target temperature for 0.5 h are observed and shown in Fig. 4(e). All electrolyte membranes are relatively stable before 50 °C, showing negligible dimensional changes. However, as the temperature rises to 100 °C, the PEO electrolyte softens and the PP film shrinks significantly. In addition, when the temperature reaches 150 °C, PEO and PP are completely destroyed, while no obvious dimensional change occurs in QSE-PxIy. The shrinkage of the electrolyte membrane can lead to a short circuit inside the battery, resulting in a safety accident, whereas high thermal stability QSE-PxIy is helpful to improving battery safety performance [27].

The QSE-PxIy produced by in situ thermal polymerization can improve the electrode/electrolyte interface characteristics while increasing the room-temperature ionic conductivity, electrochemical stability window, and ion transference number. Fig. 5 (a) shows the trend of the ionic conductivity of QSE-PxIy as a function of temperature. The ionic conductivities of QSE-PxIy formed by polymerization of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI in different proportions shows a large gap at 30 °C, in which QSE-P1I2 reaches 2.15 × 10−4 S cm−1, 4 times higher than QSE-P3I1 (4.9 × 10−5 S cm−1). The improvement of QSE-PxIy ionic conductivity may be due to the following reasons: 1) The dielectric constant of carbonyl group is higher than that of ethoxyl group, which is more conducive to the dissociation of lithium salt; 2) The interaction between TFSI− and quaternary ammonium salt cations also promotes lithium salt dissociation; 3) The proper ratio of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI can form a continuous Li+ transmission path in the electrolyte. As the amount of VBIM-TFSI in the electrolyte grows, so does its ionic conductivity due to the fact that VBIM-TFSI contains carbonyl groups and quaternary ammonium salt. When the molar ratio of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI in the electrolyte is 1:2, the complete dissociation of the lithium salt can be achieved. PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI are also sufficient to form a complete Li+ transport channel at this time, so QSE-P1I2 has the highest ion conductivity. Furthermore, since the total molar amounts of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI in the electrolyte are constant, the content of PEGMEM decrease with increasing ionic liquid content. Meanwhile, the ion transport paths in electrolyte may be destroyed due to the large volume of ionic liquid. Therefore, when the molar ratio of PEGMEM to VBIM-TFSI is 1:3, the ionic conductivity of the QSE-P1I3 decreases. In addition, the activation energy (Ea) of lithium-ion diffusion in QSE-P1I2 is calculated to be 0.151 eV according to the Arrhenius equation [43,44], indicating that Li+ has a low migration barrier in QSE-P1I2, which is beneficial to enhance ion migration and thus greatly improve ionic conductance [45].

Fig. 5(b) presents the electrochemical stability window of QSE-PxIy, which was measured by linear sweep voltammetry. The potential corresponding to the intersection of the two tangent lines is the onset potential of electrolyte decomposition. The QSE-PxIy formed by in-situ polymerization of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI with different ratios all exhibits high electrochemical stability windows. When the applied voltage of QSE-P1I2 reaches about 4.8 V, the corresponding current begins to increase and the electrolyte decomposes [46]. The optimal electrochemical stability window of QSE-P1I2 depends on the wide electrochemical stability window of the ionic liquid and the coordination formed between VBIM-TFSI and PEGMEM. The high electrochemical stability indicates that QSE-PxIy may meet the requirements of high voltage electrode, which is helpful to improve the battery capacity [47]. Furthermore, cyclic voltammetry was used to explore the reversibility of lithium plating/stripping at the QSE-P1I2/electrode interface, as shown in Fig. 5(c). The reduction peak at −0.6 V corresponds to the deposition of lithium ions on the stainless steel sheet, while the oxidation peak at 0.49 V indicates the dissolution of lithium [48]. The multiple redox curves almost coincide, indicating that QSE-P1I2 forms a stable interface with the electrode, and lithium ions can achieve stable plating/stripping [49].

The tLi + is a manifestation of the transport capacity of Li+ in electrolyte. The tLi + of the QSE-P1I2 is analyzed by steady-state current method and the result is shown in Fig. 5(d). The current changes from 9.19 × 10−5 A in the original state reduced to 6.38 × 10−5 A, while the interfacial impedance increases from 64 to 74 Ω, resulting in a calculated Li-ion transference number of 0.54, which is significantly greater than that of most solid-state electrolytes (detail in Table S2). The outstanding tLi + of QSE-P1I2 is attributed to the inhibition of the movement of TFSI− motion by the VBIM+ in the polymer backbone and cross-linked network. Higher tLi + reduces concentration polarization and improve the rate capability [50]. In addition, the creation of a space charge layer on the surface of the lithium anode is inhibited, thereby suppressing lithium dendrite growth [44].

Good electrolyte/electrode interfacial compatibility and Li+ stable plating/stripping are critical for long-term battery stability. To research the electrochemical cycling stability of QSE-PxIy, Li||QSE-PxIy||Li batteries were assembled and performed at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2. Fig. S4 shows the voltage-time curves of Li||QSE-PxIy||Li under constant current density. All electrolytes showed stable plating/stripping. Long-cycle testing on Li||QSE-P1I2||Li showed that the battery had a capacity of 0.05 mAh cm−2 and remained stable for 1000 h with no voltage fluctuations, as shown in Fig. 5(e). In addition, QSE-P1I2 was also able to achieve stable cycling at large current densities (Fig. S4(e)). This indicates that QSE-PxIy has good interfacial compatibility with lithium electrodes and can realize stable Li plating/stripping. The lithium plating/stripping performance of QSE-P1I2 under different current gradients was also investigated, and no voltage fluctuations or short-circuit failures were observed at each step (Fig. 5(f)). QSE-P1I2 can effectively regulate the deposition/dissolution of Li+ on the electrode, thereby suppressing the formation of Li dendrites [51].

LiFePO4||Li batteries with QSE-P1I2 as electrolyte are assembled, and its electrochemical performance is further investigated by charging-discharging test. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), cyclic voltammetry was used to analyze the electrochemical reaction process during the cycling of LiFePO4||QSE-P1I2||Li at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. The oxidation/reduction peaks at 3.21 V and 3.62 V in the first CV curve correspond to the delamination and intercalation of LiFePO4. The redox peaks shifted from 3.21 to 3.62 V to 3.19 and 3.64 V in the subsequent scans, which was due to the irreversible passivation layer formed. In addition, the third and fourth scanning curves basically coincide, indicating that QSE-P1I2 has good compatibility with the electrode and can realize stable oxidation-reduction of the battery. The long-term capacity retention of the batteries is shown in Fig. 6(b), which exhibit an initial discharge capacity of 162 mAh g−1 and a stable capacity of 156.2 mAh g−1 with capacity retention of 96% after 200 cycles. Meanwhile, the voltage-capacity curves of the 1st, 50th, 100th, 150th and 200th cycles are extracted in Fig. 6(c). The curves show low polarization voltage (78 mV) and excellent cycle stability, which is attributed to the high Li+ conductivity and Li+ transference number of QSE-P1I2, as well as excellent electrode/electrolyte compatibility [52]. In addition, the polarization voltage has increased slightly with the progress of cycling, which may be because the solid electrolyte layer (SEI) develops on the surface of the lithium anode, increasing the battery's internal resistance [39]. Besides, we further investigated the charge–discharge cycling of LiFePO4||QSE-P1I2||Li batteries at room temperature (Fig. 6(d)). The electrolyte with excellent ionic conductivity enables the batteries to exhibit more than 100 stable cycles at 0.1 C with a capacity of 115.4 mAh g−1 without significant fading. However, the cycling stability of the battery is somewhat fluctuating, since the room temperature is not constant, which varies with the ambient temperature. Fig. 6(e) shows the cycle stability under different current densities of LiFePO4||Li battery based on QSE-P1I2 at 0.1–1 C. The initial discharge capacities at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1C are 158.8, 146.5, 124.9 and 99.5 mAh g−1 at 60 °C, respectively. When the current density recovers to 0.1C, the capacity remains 93.7% of the starting value. The above results suggest that QSE-P1I2 can provide a stable interface of electrode/electrolyte and improve the cycling stability [53].

The assembled LiCoO2||Li battery was tested in the voltage range of 3–4.2 V at a current density of 0.1 C at ambient temperature to evaluate the applicability of QSE-P1I2 under high-voltage electrodes, as shown in Fig. 6(f). The LiCoO2||Li battery exhibits high cycling stability, with high specific discharge capacity (132.6 mAh g−1) and capacity retention (92.1%) after 100 cycles. From the voltage-specific capacity curves in Fig. S8, the charge-discharge capacities at the 50th and 100th cycles almost overlap, showing the stability of the LiCoO2||Li battery. In addition, we also assembled an NCM811||Li battery and investigated cycling performance at ambient temperature with a current density of 0.1 C. From Fig. S5(b), the NCM811||Li battery also exhibits high cycling stability, which is mainly attributed to the high ionic conductivity, wide electrochemical stability window and good electrode/electrolyte interfacial compatibility.

To explore the application potential of solid lithium metal batteries with QSE-P1I2 as electrolyte in flexible devices and their safety under different extreme conditions [54,55], LiFePO4||Li pouch batteries were assembled. As shown in Fig. 6(h), the battery exhibits stable reversible cycling at a current density of 0.1 C at 60 °C. The charge-discharge curves with different cycles (Fig. S5(c)) show stable voltage polarization, showing that the battery has strong reversibility. Furthermore, due to all-solid-state lithium metal battery's flexibility, it lights up the light emitting diode (LED) under the conditions of normal (Fig. 6g2) and folding angles of 90° (Fig. 6g3). In addition, the manufactured battery retains the ability to light the LED even if one corner (Fig. 6g4) or half (Fig. 6g5) is cut off. Furthermore, the half-length battery still has an output voltage of 3.4 V (Fig. 6g6). These results demonstrate the reliability of QSE-P1I2 in Li-metal batteries and a lot of potential in the realm of flexible wearable electronics.

The interface performance of electrolyte/electrode is investigated by analyzing the surface morphology of the cycled electrode and the chemical composition of the solid electrolyte interface layer (SEI). Cathode morphology and X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping (Fig. S6) after LiFePO4||QSE-P1I2||Li charge-discharge cycles indicate that the electrolyte precursor infiltrated the LiFePO4 electrode before polymerization and aggregated in the cathode to create a continuous ion transport pathway, thereby improving the cathode/electrolyte interface performance. Fig. 7 (a) shows the SEM images of the pristine Li foil and cycled Li foil. The surface of the cycled Li foil had a small amount of Li dendrites, while the surface of the pristine Li foil was flat. However, the accumulation of undesirable products can be negligible, which indicates that a stable SEI layer develops on the electrode surface. XPS analysis of SEI layer on lithium metal can reveal the reason cause of QSE-P1I2 improves the electrolyte/electrode interface. As shown in Fig. 7(b), C1s observed five peaks at 284.5, 286.3, 288.3, 289.8 and 292.6 eV, corresponding to C–C, C–O–C, –COOR, –CO3 2- and –CFx, respectively. Generally, the peaks of carbon oxides are mainly formed by the reduction of PEGMEM and carbonate solvent, while the peak at 292.6 eV is attributed to the interaction of PVDF with lithium metal [56–58]. The peaks at 688.5 and 684.7 eV in the F 1s spectrum are –CFx and LiF, which are generated by the decomposition or defluorination of PVDF [59,60]. LiF with low electronic conductivity, li-ion diffusion barrier and high surface energy is contributing to the uniform deposition of lithium ions on the electrode [61]. Furthermore, the peaks of N+ (400.9 eV) and Li3N (398.3 eV) in N 1s spectrum were detected due to the decomposition of ionic liquids and lithium salts [62,63]. Li3N, a kind of superionic conductor, has stability to lithium metal, which is beneficial to reduce the continuous side reaction between electrolyte and lithium metal [57,61]. Therefore, the SEI layer with LiF and Li3N can prevent Li dendrite development and improve the electrolyte/electrode interface performance.

The poly(ionic liquid) quasi-solid electrolytes (QSEs), reinforced by polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS)/polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) electrospun membrane, are designed and prepared by in-situ thermally initiated polymerization for lithium metal battery. The quasi-solid electrolyte (QSE-P1I2) with molar ratio of PEGMEM and VBIM-TFSI of 1–2 shows good thermal stability and mechanical strength due to the excellent thermal stability of ionic liquids and POSS, as well as the formation of a double network structure. The QSE-P1I2 exhibits higher ionic conductivity (2.15 × 10−4 S cm−1, 30 °C), improved mechanical strength and ductility, and electrode/electrolyte interfacial compatibility. When used as an electrolyte for rechargeable lithium metal batteries, the battery with QSE-P1I2 exhibits a reversible capacity of up to 160 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C at 60 °C. More impressively, the cell exhibits excellent cycling stability at room temperature. Furthermore, the safety performance of the LiFePO4||QSE-P1I2||Li pouch battery is investigated under extreme conditions such as bending and cutting. We believe the in-situ preparation method with simple operation and simplified process, as well as excellent electrochemical performance of QSE-PxIy will provide a new strategy for the long-life work of all solid-state batteries at ambient temperature.
